title: Douglas Fowley
text:
Douglas Fowley (born Daniel Vincent Fowley, May 30, 1911 – May 21, 1998) was an American movie and television actor in more than 240 films and dozens of television programs, He is probably best remembered for his role as the frustrated movie director Roscoe Dexter in "<a href="Singin%27%20in%20the%20Rain">Singin' in the Rain</a>" (1952), and for his regular supporting role as <a href="Doc%20Holliday">Doc Holliday</a> in "<a href="The%20Life%20and%20Legend%20of%20Wyatt%20Earp">The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp</a>". He is the father of rock and roll musician and record producer <a href="Kim%20Fowley">Kim Fowley</a>.
Early years.
Fowley was born in <a href="The%20Bronx%2C%20New%20York">The Bronx</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. He began acting while attending St. Francis Xavier Military Academy. He later attended <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20College">Los Angeles City College</a>.
Fowley began as a singing waiter and then worked as a copy boy for "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>", a runner for a Wall Street broker, a <a href="United%20States%20Postal%20Service">United States Postal Service</a> employee, a barker, a salesman, a professional football player, and finally a professional actor.
Military service.
Fowley's enlistment in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> led to his being wounded when he served on an aircraft carrier in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>.
He was aboard an aircraft carrier when an explosion knocked out his teeth. The dental setback hardly slowed his career as an actor. In fact, he ended up portraying one of the most well-known dentists in American history. "I had a false upper plate, having lost my upper teeth prematurely in mid-life," he explained to Western Clippings in 1994. "I started playing old character roles by removing my false upper plate, adding a beard, voice and gait to match my interpretation."
Film.
After nightclub performing and stage work, Fowley appeared in 1933 in his first film, "The Mad Game", alongside <a href="Spencer%20Tracy">Spencer Tracy</a>. Early in his acting career, he was usually cast as a movie heavy or gangster in B-movies, including <a href="Charlie%20Chan">Charlie Chan</a> and <a href="Laurel%20and%20Hardy">Laurel and Hardy</a> features.
Fowley's films include "<a href="Twenty%20Mule%20Team%20%281940%20film%29">Twenty Mule Team</a>", "<a href="Fall%20Guy%20%281947%20film%29">Fall Guy</a>", "<a href="Mighty%20Joe%20Young%20%281949%20film%29">Mighty Joe Young</a>", "<a href="Angels%20in%20the%20Outfield%20%281951%20film%29">Angels in the Outfield</a>", "<a href="Battleground%20%28film%29">Battleground</a>", "<a href="Armored%20Car%20Robbery">Armored Car Robbery</a>", "<a href="Chick%20Carter%2C%20Detective">Chick Carter, Detective</a>", "<a href="The%20Naked%20Jungle">The Naked Jungle</a>", "<a href="The%20High%20and%20the%20Mighty%20%28film%29">The High and the Mighty</a>", and "<a href="Walking%20Tall%20%281973%20film%29">Walking Tall</a>".
Television.
Regular cast.
For several seasons, Fowley played the key supporting role of <a href="Doc%20Holliday">John H. "Doc" Holliday</a> in the 1955-1961 <a href="western%20%28genre%29">western</a> television series "<a href="The%20Life%20and%20Legend%20of%20Wyatt%20Earp">The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp</a>" after having appeared as Doc Fabrique in the show's premiere season. This role allowed Fowley to demonstrate his flair for comedy and other acting skills as a clever, sharp-witted, sardonic, cynical, alcoholic, poker-playing foil to the square-jawed, milk-drinking, church-going Wyatt Earp (<a href="Hugh%20O%27Brian">Hugh O'Brian</a>), whom Holiday nicknamed "Deacon" due to his rigid sense of morality. Not at all so encumbered Doc would occasionally take the law into his own hands behind Earp's back to protect his friend from legal action or even death when the marshal was legally or morally ham-strung. Holliday, as played by Fowley, having no problem working around morals or the law, could be either hilarious or cold-blooded.
From 1966 to 1967, Fowley portrayed Andrew Hanks in "<a href="Pistols%20%27n%27%20Petticoats">Pistols 'n' Petticoats</a>", a CBS sitcom. Hanks was the <a href="patriarch">patriarch</a> in a family of gun-toting women who seemed to have little need for male assistance.
Fowley portrayed retired businessman Robert Redford in "<a href="Detective%20School">Detective School</a>" (1979).
Guest appearances.
In the 1950s, he appeared as himself on <a href="National%20Broadcasting%20Company">NBC</a>'s "<a href="The%20Donald%20O%27Connor%20Show">The Donald O'Connor Show</a>". In 1954, he demonstrated his comic appeal when he appeared alongside <a href="Gracie%20Allen">Gracie Allen</a> in "<a href="The%20George%20Burns%20and%20Gracie%20Allen%20Show">The George Burns and Gracie Allen Show</a>". He was cast in 1956 as Bob Egan in the "Two-Fisted Saint" episode of the religious <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> "<a href="Crossroads%20%281955%20TV%20series%29">Crossroads</a>". He portrayed a con man in two episodes of the NBC sitcom "<a href="It%27s%20a%20Great%20Life%20%28TV%20series%29">It's a Great Life</a>". He also guest-starred on <a href="Reed%20Hadley">Reed Hadley</a>'s <a href="Columbia%20Broadcasting%20Company">CBS</a> <a href="legal%20drama">legal drama</a> "<a href="The%20Public%20Defender%20%28TV%20series%29">The Public Defender</a>". He appeared, too, on the ABC <a href="situation%20comedy">situation comedy</a> "<a href="The%20Pride%20of%20the%20Family">The Pride of the Family</a>" and on the NBC Western series "<a href="The%20Californians%20%28TV%20series%29">The Californians</a>" and "<a href="Jefferson%20Drum">Jefferson Drum</a>". He was cast on two <a href="Rod%20Cameron%20%28actor%29">Rod Cameron</a> series, the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> "<a href="City%20Detective%20%28TV%20series%29">City Detective</a>" and the Western-themed "<a href="State%20Trooper%20%28TV%20series%29">State Trooper</a>", and in <a href="John%20Bromfield">John Bromfield</a>'s series, "<a href="Sheriff%20of%20Cochise">U.S. Marshal</a>". He guest-starred in the <a href="David%20Janssen">David Janssen</a> crime drama "<a href="Richard%20Diamond%2C%20Private%20Detective">Richard Diamond, Private Detective</a>" and guest-starred in season two, episode four of the Robert Culp Western "Trackdown".
In 1959, Fowley appeared with <a href="Frank%20Ferguson">Frank Ferguson</a> in the episode "A Race for Life" of the CBS Western series "<a href="The%20Texan%20%28TV%20series%29">The Texan</a>", starring <a href="Rory%20Calhoun">Rory Calhoun</a>.
In 1964, Fowley made a guest appearance on the CBS courtroom drama series "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" playing agent Rubin Cason in "The Case of the Bountiful Beauty". In 1965, he was cast as Sorrowful in episode 83 of the series "The Virginian". 
In 1966, he appeared as "Rufus C. Hoops" in "The Search" season 2, episode 24, of the series "Daniel Boone". Original air date for this episode was March 3, 1966. In 1967, Fowley guest-starred on the short-lived CBS Western "<a href="Dundee%20and%20the%20Culhane">Dundee and the Culhane</a>" with <a href="John%20Mills">John Mills</a>.
In 1968, he appeared in episode 273 of "<a href="My%20Three%20Sons">My Three Sons</a>" as an old pal of Uncle Charley's. He had a role in the syndicated 1959-1960 Western "<a href="Pony%20Express%20%28TV%20series%29">Pony Express</a>" in the episode "Showdown at Thirty Mile Ridge". He was cast in 1963 in "<a href="Miracle%20of%20the%20White%20Stallions">Miracle of the White Stallions</a>".
Fowley was usually typecast as a villain; when not playing an actual criminal, he often portrayed an argumentative troublemaker. Portraying a member of <a href="Tyrone%20Power">Tyrone Power</a>'s orchestra in "<a href="Alexander%27s%20Ragtime%20Band%20%28film%29">Alexander's Ragtime Band</a>", in the early scenes of the film, Fowley's character quarrels with his bandmates, but this is not developed in the film's later scenes.
Fowley continued to act into the 1970s and was frequently billed as "Douglas V. Fowley". One of his last roles was as Delaney Rafferty in Disney's "<a href="The%20North%20Avenue%20Irregulars">The North Avenue Irregulars</a>", in which he dressed in <a href="drag%20%28clothing%29">drag</a>.
Personal life.
Fowley was married eight times and had six children. His first marriage was to a woman named Maria. He remarried to Marjorie Reid in 1935, they divorced the next year. Fowley later married to actress Shelby Payne in 1938 and divorced in 1943. He then married to Mary Rose Hunter in 1944 and later to Vivian M. Chambers in 1947. Fowley then was to Joy A. Torstup from 1950 to 1954 and later to Judy Walsh the following year and divorced in 1956.
Finally, Fowley married Jean Louise Paschall on 1961, and they remained together until Douglas's death. His children where Douglas Jr., Kim, Daniel, Gretchen and Kip.
Death.
Fowley died nine days before what would have been his 87th birthday. He was buried at the <a href="Murrieta%2C%20California%23Cemetery">Murrieta, California, Laurel Cemetery</a>.
